question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very
carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be
considered for this problem).

Does the integral

\begin{align*}\int_1^{\infty} \frac {x^2}{x^3+2x+5} \,dx\end{align*} converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
sols:
The difference between the highest exponents is 3 - 2 = 1. By the
intergral \emph{p} test (with \emph{p} = 1) this integral diverges.

More precisely we estimate the integral with

\begin{align*}\int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x + 5}dx > \int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x^3 + 5x^3}dx = \frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx\end{align*}

Here we see exactly how to use the integral \emph{p} test. We also can
continue with the anti-derivative

\begin{align*}\frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}[\text{ln}(x)]_1^\alpha = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}\text{ln}(\alpha)=\infty\end{align*}
hints:
If you do not know how to use the integral \emph{p} test, estimate the
integral with a lower bound first.
